question:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of India?

SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024
option_1: Article 30 of the Constitution of India gives the Supreme Court wide original jurisdiction.
option_2: Original jurisdiction extends to any dispute between the Government of India and one or more states.
option_3: The Supreme Court has very wide advisory jurisdiction over all courts and tribunals in India.
option_4: The original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court can be exercised by a certificate granted by the High Court.
solution:
Original jurisdiction means the power of a court to hear a case for the first time, not on appeal.

As per Article 131 of the Indian Constitution, the Supreme Court has original jurisdiction in disputes involving:

The Government of India and one or more states, or

Between two or more states.

This jurisdiction is exclusive, meaning no other court can decide such cases.

Why other options are wrong:

Article 30 deals with minorities' rights, not Supreme Court jurisdiction.

Advisory jurisdiction is limited and defined in Article 143, not “very wide”.

Certificate jurisdiction relates to appellate jurisdiction under Article 132, not original.

question:
In which year was the first-ever motion to remove a Supreme Court Justice signed by the members of Parliament?

SSC MTS 15/10/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
The first-ever motion to remove a Supreme Court judge in India was moved in 1991.

The motion was aimed at Justice V. Ramaswami, who was accused of financial and administrative irregularities during his tenure as Chief Justice of the Punjab and Haryana High Court.

Though the motion was brought in Lok Sabha and supported by several MPs, it failed due to abstentions by ruling party members during voting.

Additional Points:

This was the first instance of an impeachment motion against a Supreme Court judge in Indian history.

Impeachment of judges is governed by Article 124(4) and the Judges (Inquiry) Act, 1968.

No judge of the Supreme Court or High Court has ever been successfully removed till date.

question:
Which Article of the Constitution of India grants power to the President to appoint Judges of the Supreme Court?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
Article 124(2) of the Indian Constitution empowers the President of India to appoint Judges of the Supreme Court.

The President appoints:

The Chief Justice of India (CJI), and

Other Supreme Court Judges

After consultation with the CJI and other judges as deemed necessary.

This Article is part of the framework ensuring judicial independence.

Related Facts:

The Collegium System, though not mentioned in the Constitution, evolved through Supreme Court judgments and is used in recommending names for appointment.

The age of retirement for SC judges is 65 years.

Appointed judges take an oath before the President of India under the Third Schedule.

question:
The Supreme Court of India comprises the Chief Justice and not more than ______ other Judges appointed by the President of India.

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
As per Article 124(1) of the Constitution and the Supreme Court (Number of Judges) Amendment Act, 2019, the sanctioned strength of the Supreme Court includes:

1 Chief Justice of India (CJI)

33 other Judges

Hence, the total strength of the Supreme Court is 34 judges.

All these judges are appointed by the President of India as per the procedure laid down in Article 124(2).

Additional Facts:

Prior to the 2019 amendment, the number of judges (excluding CJI) was 30.

The increase was made to address the issue of pending cases and judicial backlog.

question:
Articles 214 to 231 in Part VI of the Indian Constitution deal with the ____.

SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
Articles 214 to 231 of the Indian Constitution fall under Part VI, which deals with the State Judiciary.

These specific Articles relate to the High Courts in the states.

They cover:

Establishment of High Courts (Article 214)

Appointment and qualifications of judges

Jurisdiction and powers of High Courts

Transfer of judges and acting Chief Justices

Salaries, tenure, and independence of High Court judges

Additional Points:

Article 214: There shall be a High Court for each state.

Article 226: Grants High Courts the power to issue writs — wider than that of the Supreme Court under Article 32.

Article 222: (Not in this range, but related) deals with transfer of judges from one High Court to another.

question:
Which writ is issued by a high court or supreme court when a lower court has considered a case going beyond its jurisdiction?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
The Writ of Prohibition is issued by a Higher Court (High Court or Supreme Court) to a lower court or tribunal, directing it to stop proceedings in a case that is beyond its legal jurisdiction.

It is preventive in nature, i.e., issued before the judgment is delivered.

This writ ensures that lower courts do not exceed their authority or act contrary to the law.

Difference from Certiorari:

Prohibition: Issued before the decision to prevent overreach.

Certiorari: Issued after the decision to quash an illegal order or judgment.

question:
In which judgement did the Supreme Court extend the scope of Article 21 and observed that ‘the Right to education flows directly from the ‘Right to life’?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift)
option_1: Mohini Jain v State of Karnataka
option_2: Neerja Choudhari v State of M. P.
option_3: Kharak Singh v State of UP
option_4: Malak Singh v State of Punjab
solution:
In Mohini Jain v. State of Karnataka (1992), the Supreme Court of India held that the Right to Education is an integral part of the Right to Life under Article 21.

The court stated that without education, the right to life is meaningless, as it denies individuals the opportunity to live with dignity.

This judgment played a key role in laying the foundation for making education a Fundamental Right, later formalized in Article 21A by the 86th Constitutional Amendment (2002).

Additional Points:

This was later reaffirmed and expanded in the Unnikrishnan v. State of Andhra Pradesh (1993) case.

Article 21A, introduced in 2002, guarantees free and compulsory education to children aged 6–14 years.

question:
Which of the following organisations said that India CANNOT have a parallel judicial system- one for the rich and the other for the poor?

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
The Supreme Court of India made a strong observation that India cannot afford to have two parallel judicial systems—one for the rich and influential, and another for the poor and underprivileged.

The Court emphasized that equal access to justice is a fundamental right and the judiciary must remain fair, impartial, and accessible to all citizens.

This statement was made in light of growing concerns about delays, inequality, and preferential treatment in the legal process.

Additional Points:

The remark highlights the importance of Article 14 (Right to Equality) and Article 21 (Right to Life and Liberty) which ensure equal treatment before the law.

The judiciary has often reiterated that justice should not depend on one’s economic or social status.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that the law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all the courts within the territory of India?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
Article 141 of the Indian Constitution states:

"The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India."

This means that once the Supreme Court interprets or declares a law, it becomes the legal precedent and must be followed by all lower courts.

This ensures uniformity of law and promotes judicial discipline and consistency across the country.

Additional Points:

Article 141 strengthens the Supreme Court’s role as the final interpreter of the Constitution and law.

It does not bind the Parliament, but is binding on all subordinate courts, including High Courts.

question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of India?

A. Original jurisdiction extends to any dispute between the Government of India and one or more States or between the Government of India and any State or States on one side and one or more States on the other or between two or more States.

B. Appellate Jurisdiction extends when the Union plus some States are one side and some other States on the other side of the dispute.

C. Under Articles 129 and 142 of the Constitution, the Supreme Court has been vested with the power to punish for contempt of court.

D. As of now, the International Commercial Arbitration cannot be initiated in the Supreme Court.

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: B and D only
option_2: A and C only
option_3: A, B, C and D
option_4: A and B only
solution:
✔ A – Correct:

Article 131 grants the Supreme Court original jurisdiction in disputes between:

Government of India and one or more States

Between two or more States

Or the Union and some States on one side and other States on the other

✖ B – Incorrect:

This describes a scenario under original, not appellate jurisdiction.

Appellate jurisdiction involves appeals from lower courts in constitutional, civil, or criminal matters — not inter-government disputes.

✔ C – Correct:

Article 129: Declares the Supreme Court as a court of record, with power to punish for contempt.

Article 142: Empowers the Court to pass any order necessary for complete justice, which includes contempt powers.

✖ D – Incorrect:

As per the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, and subsequent amendments, International Commercial Arbitration (ICA) can be initiated under the Supreme Court’s jurisdiction (in cases under Section 11).

question:
The advisory board under provisions of Article 22 of the Constitution is to be consisted of persons who are, or have been or are qualified to be appointed as __________.

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)
option_1: Judges of Supreme court
option_2: Judges of Lower court
option_3: Judges of High court
option_4: Judges of District court
solution:
Article 22 of the Indian Constitution deals with protection against arrest and detention in certain cases, especially preventive detention.

When a person is detained preventively, the case must be referred to an Advisory Board within 3 months.

This Advisory Board is required to consist of persons who are, have been, or are qualified to be appointed as Judges of a High Court.

The Board reviews whether the detention is valid and justified.

Additional Points:

If the Advisory Board finds the detention unjustified, the person must be released.

This provision is aimed at safeguarding fundamental rights under preventive detention laws.

question:
The Federal Court of India was established in Delhi by the Act of ______.

Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
The Federal Court of India was established in Delhi under the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935.

It began functioning from 1st October 1937 and served as the highest judicial authority in British India until the Supreme Court was established in 1950.

The Federal Court had jurisdiction to:

Resolve disputes between provinces and the British government.

Hear appeals from High Courts on constitutional matters.

Additional Points:

The first Chief Justice of the Federal Court was Sir Maurice Gwyer.

It was replaced by the Supreme Court of India on 26th January 1950 under the new Constitution.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that there shall be a Supreme Court of India?

Graduate Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
Article 124(1) of the Indian Constitution clearly states:

“There shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of a Chief Justice and, until Parliament by law prescribes a larger number, of not more than seven other Judges.”

This Article provides the constitutional basis for the establishment of the Supreme Court, the highest judicial authority in India.

The Supreme Court was formally established on 26 January 1950, replacing the Federal Court of India.

Additional Facts:

The current strength of the Supreme Court (after the 2019 amendment) is 34 judges (including the Chief Justice).

The Supreme Court has original, appellate, and advisory jurisdiction.

question:
Disputes between two or more states come under the _______ of the Supreme Court.

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
Such disputes fall under the Original Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court as per Article 131 of the Indian Constitution.

Original jurisdiction means the Supreme Court has the authority to hear the case directly, without it coming from a lower court.

It applies to:

Disputes between the Government of India and one or more States

Or between two or more States

Important Note:

This jurisdiction is exclusive — no other court can handle such disputes.

question:
In which of the following cases the Supreme Court, while laying out the 'basic structure' of the Constitution held that the democratic character of the polity was an essential component of the 'basic structure"?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)
option_1: Romesh Thappar vs State of Madras
option_2: AK Gopalan vs State of Madras
option_3: Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala
option_4: Sajjan Singh vs State of Rajasthan
solution:
In the landmark Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973) case, the Supreme Court introduced the ‘Basic Structure Doctrine’.

The Court ruled that while Parliament has wide powers to amend the Constitution, it cannot alter the “basic structure” or fundamental framework of the Constitution.

Among the elements identified as part of the basic structure were:

Democratic character of the polity

Rule of law

Separation of powers

Fundamental rights, etc.

Additional Points:

The judgment acted as a check on Parliament’s amending power under Article 368.

It laid the foundation for judicial review of constitutional amendments.

question:
The State of Kerala Vs Leesamma Joseph case deals with __________.

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (2nd shift)
option_2: the economic weaker section
solution:
The State of Kerala vs Leesamma Joseph case is a significant judgment related to the rights of persons with disabilities.

The Supreme Court of India ruled that equal pay and service benefits should be provided to persons with disabilities, especially those working on a contractual or temporary basis in government services.

The Court emphasized that discrimination on the basis of disability violates Articles 14 (Right to Equality) and 21 (Right to Life and Dignity) of the Constitution.

Additional Points:

The judgment reinforced the equal treatment principle under the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016.

It aims to ensure non-discrimination, equal opportunity, and dignity for disabled individuals in employment.

question:
The Supreme Court of India came into existence on ___________ .

SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
The Supreme Court of India came into existence on 26 January 1950, the same day the Constitution of India came into effect.

It replaced the Federal Court of India, which had been functioning since 1937 under the Government of India Act, 1935.

The Supreme Court was established as the highest judicial authority of independent India to uphold the Constitution and rule of law.

Additional Points:

The Court initially functioned from the Chamber of Princes in Parliament House until it moved to its current building on Tilak Marg, New Delhi, in 1958.

The first Chief Justice of India was Justice H. J. Kania.

question:
Till which year did the High Court of Delhi continue to exercise jurisdiction over Himachal Pradesh?

SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
The High Court of Delhi exercised judicial jurisdiction over Himachal Pradesh until the year 1971.

This continued until Himachal Pradesh attained full statehood on 25th January 1971.

Following statehood, a separate High Court for Himachal Pradesh was established in Shimla.

Additional Points:

Himachal Pradesh was earlier a Union Territory, and thus judicial matters were handled by the Delhi High Court.

After becoming the 18th state of India, it got its own independent High Court under the provisions of the State of Himachal Pradesh Act, 1970.

question:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the Family Courts (Amendment) Bill, 2022?

Graduate Level 27/06/2023 (Shift- 4)

The Family Courts (Amendment) Bill was introduced in Lok Sabha on 18 July 2022.

2. The Bill amends the Family Courts Act, 1984.

3. The Act allows state governments to establish Family Courts.

4. The Act is not applicable in Punjab and Tamil Nadu.
solution:
Statement 1 – Correct:

The Family Courts (Amendment) Bill, 2022 was introduced in the Lok Sabha on 18 July 2022 by the Minister of Law and Justice.

The aim was to regularize family courts established by states without proper central notification, as required under the Family Courts Act, 1984.

Statement 2 – Correct:

The Bill amends the Family Courts Act, 1984, which was originally enacted to:

Establish Family Courts to handle marriage, divorce, child custody, and maintenance-related cases.

Promote conciliation and ensure speedy disposal of family disputes.

Statement 3 – Correct:

The original 1984 Act empowers State Governments to set up Family Courts in consultation with their respective High Courts.

These courts deal exclusively with family matters, and have civil jurisdiction.

Statement 4 – Incorrect:

The Act is applicable in Punjab and Tamil Nadu.

The amendment was brought to legally validate family courts already functioning in Himachal Pradesh and Nagaland, which had started operations without being notified by the Central Government, as required.

So, Punjab and Tamil Nadu were never outside the purview of the Act.

Conclusion:

  • Hence, only statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

question:
The High court of Delhi was established in _______.

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
The Delhi High Court was established on 31st October 1966 under the Delhi High Court Act, 1966.

Before 1966, the Union Territory of Delhi was under the jurisdiction of the Punjab High Court, and its benches used to sit in Delhi to handle cases.

As the volume of legal work grew due to Delhi’s rising population and administrative importance, a separate High Court was created to serve the capital more effectively.

The first Chief Justice of the Delhi High Court was Justice K. S. Hegde, who later became a judge in the Supreme Court of India.

The court exercises original jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters, writ jurisdiction under Article 226, and appellate jurisdiction over lower courts within Delhi.

Important Note:

The Delhi High Court is one of the youngest High Courts in India but among the most prominent due to its location in the national capital.

It also supervises District Courts of Delhi, and has several benches, including one dealing with commercial and intellectual property matters, making it highly significant in modern jurisprudence.

question:
The first High Court in India was established in ______________ .

SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
The first High Courts in India were established on 1st July 1862, under the authority of the Indian High Courts Act of 1861 passed by the British Parliament.

On this day, three High Courts were set up in the Presidency towns of:

Calcutta (now Kolkata)

Bombay (now Mumbai)

Madras (now Chennai)

These courts replaced the earlier Supreme Courts and Sadar Adalats that operated under colonial rule.

The Calcutta High Court is considered the oldest High Court in India.

Additional Facts:

The Indian High Courts Act, 1861, allowed the Crown to establish High Courts in various provinces.

These High Courts had civil, criminal, admiralty, and equity jurisdiction.

Later, more High Courts were established, and after independence, they became part of the integrated Indian judiciary.

question:
In which of the following cases did the Supreme Court of India pronounce the theory of the ‘Basic Structure’ of the Constitution?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
The Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973) case is a landmark judgment where the Supreme Court of India laid down the ‘Basic Structure Doctrine’.

The Court ruled that while Parliament has the power to amend the Constitution under Article 368, it cannot alter or destroy its ‘basic structure’.

The basic structure includes elements like:

Supremacy of the Constitution

Rule of law

Judicial review

Secularism, democracy, federalism, and fundamental rights

Additional Facts:

The judgment was delivered by a 13-judge bench, the largest ever in Indian judicial history.

The case arose when Kesavananda Bharati, a seer from Kerala, challenged state land reform laws affecting his property.

The ruling saved the Constitution from unlimited parliamentary power and became the foundation of constitutional governance in India.

question:
What is the structure of the Indian judiciary?

SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
The Indian judiciary follows a three-tier system, meaning it has three levels of courts, arranged in a hierarchical structure:

  1. Supreme Court (at the top) – Apex court of India
  2. High Courts (at the state level) – One for each state or group of states
  3. Subordinate/District Courts (at the district and local level)

This structure ensures a clear path of appeal and review, providing access to justice from the grassroots to the national level.

Additional Points:

The Supreme Court is established under Article 124 and is the guardian of the Constitution.

High Courts are defined in Articles 214 to 231.

District and subordinate courts are under the control of the High Courts as per Article 235.

question:
A judge of the Supreme Court can be removed only on the grounds of ______

SSC CGL 09/12/2022(1st Shift)
option_1: disrespect of the Constitution
option_2: proven misbehaviour or incapacity
solution:
As per Article 124(4) of the Indian Constitution, a Supreme Court judge can be removed from office only on the grounds of:

Proven misbehaviour, or

Incapacity

The removal process is known as impeachment and involves:

  1. A motion passed by a special majority in both Houses of Parliament.
  2. An inquiry by a committee of judges (under the Judges Inquiry Act, 1968).
  3. If found guilty, both Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha must pass the motion with a 2/3rd majority.

Additional Facts:

No Supreme Court judge has been successfully impeached in India till now.

The process is deliberately difficult to maintain judicial independence and prevent misuse of power.

question:
Which of the following jurisdictions of the Supreme Court allows it to settle disputes between the centre and state and amongst states?

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
The Original Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court is defined under Article 131 of the Indian Constitution.

This jurisdiction allows the Court to directly hear and resolve disputes:

Between the Government of India and one or more States

Or between two or more States

These cases do not go through lower courts and are heard directly by the Supreme Court.

Why other options are incorrect:

(a) Appellate: Deals with appeals from lower courts (High Courts, Tribunals).

(b) Advisory: Supreme Court gives legal advice to the President under Article 143.

(c) Writ: Concerns protection of fundamental rights under Article 32.

question:
A Supreme Court or High Court judge can be removed by the Parliament by:

SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Afternoon)
option_2: both simple and two third majority
solution:
As per Article 124(4) of the Indian Constitution, a Supreme Court or High Court judge can be removed only by Parliament and that too by a special majority.

Special Majority here means:

A majority of the total membership of each House, and

A majority of not less than two-thirds of the members present and voting.

The process is detailed in the Judges (Inquiry) Act, 1968 and is referred to as impeachment, though the word is not used in the Constitution.

Important Points:

Grounds for removal: Proven misbehaviour or incapacity

No judge has ever been successfully removed through this process in Indian history.

question:
Which is NOT correct about the independence of the judiciary in our country?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
option_1: The judiciary has the power to penalise those who are found guilty of contempt of court.
option_2: The judges are financially dependent on both the executive and legislature for their salaries and allowances.
option_3: The Constitution prescribes a very difficult procedure for removal of judges.
option_4: The legislature is not involved in the process of appointment of judges.
solution:
Correct:

The judiciary has the constitutional power to punish for contempt of court under Articles 129 and 215. This helps in maintaining its authority and independence.

(b) Not Correct (Answer):

Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts are not financially dependent on the executive or legislature.

Their salaries, allowances, and pensions are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India or the State, which cannot be voted upon in Parliament or State Legislature.

This ensures financial independence of the judiciary.

(c) Correct:

The removal of judges involves a very stringent process under Article 124(4) – requiring a special majority in both Houses of Parliament.

(d) Correct:

The legislature has no role in the appointment of judges in the present collegium system, which is handled by the judiciary itself.

Conclusion:

Only option (b) is incorrect, making it the right answer to the question.

question:
The Indian judicial system is based on:

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
option_1: both integrated and dual system
solution:
The Indian judicial system follows a single integrated judicial structure, meaning:

There is one unified judiciary for the entire country, and

The Supreme Court is at the top, followed by High Courts and Subordinate Courts.

Unlike a dual judicial system (as in the USA) where separate federal and state courts exist, India has only one system of courts for both Union and State laws.

Supreme Court decisions are binding on all courts in India (as per Article 141), ensuring uniformity in law.

Important Features:

High Courts supervise the subordinate courts within the state.

This integration ensures consistency, efficiency, and a unified interpretation of the Constitution.
